channel.title: Nexus one
channel.description:
i've been into it since like early december, and rumors say it's being released tomorrow. who is getting it? links: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nexus_One http://money.cnn.com/2010/01/04/technology/google_nexus_one/ http://www.pcworld.com/article/185423/googles_nexus_one_details_what_we_know_so_far.html http://www.engadget.com/2010/01/02/exclusive-google-nexus-one-hands-on-video-and-first-impressio/
i think i'm going to exchange my blackberry bold for one and sell my mytouch 3g :-)

item.title: Nexus one
item.dc:creator: @JaydenD12 JaydenD12
item.description:
@JaydenD12 wrote:

It sucks that it’s not available in my country. (New Zealand)

Read full topic

item.title: Nexus one
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“TeleNubby, post:16, topic:323959”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=420359.msg3088868#msg3088868 date=1262730731]
I’m not getting one, i’d pay max $50 for a new phone.
[/quote]Why? Sure all you probably need is something that calls and has the ability to vocally communicate with other phones; but still, nowadays there is more to phones than that (at least, I use phones for much more than that). Keyboards themselves are a nice bonus, but I guess you don’t text. Touch screens themselves aren’t great, but they’re usually on phones with newer capabilities and features that older cheaper phones don’t have. I don’t know about you but I prefer newer phones much more to older phones for numerous reasons.[/quote]I prefer older phones because they are generally more durable, doesn’t have annoying bugs such as sum newer phone i had last year (it hanged like once a day, i replaced and same shit happened) and battery lasts way longer.

Read full topic

item.title: Nexus one
item.dc:creator: @Stork Stork
item.description:
@Stork wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:18, topic:323959”][quote author=TeleNubby link=topic=420359.msg3089852#msg3089852 date=1262813820]
Keyboards themselves are a nice bonus, but I guess you don’t text.
[/quote]

How big is the keyboard? Because there is no feedback, the odds of hitting two keys simultaneously increase dramatically. Too small keys force you to use your index finger to type, which means you have to use two hands. You look like a tool when you do that.

So what does a modern phone have, that an older phone doesn’t? Sure, its great that a 5’ by 2.5’ device has a lot of processing power etc. But how does it put that to use, and does that add any real value to you?[/quote][quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:20, topic:323959”]It costs a shitload too. An iPhone for instance. The cheapest plan is €29,95. I have to pay another €29,95 once for the phone. I get 150 texts and 150 minutes. For the same price I can get 600 texts, 300 minutes, and a blackberry bold 9000 (just to name something). In this plan the phone is free. And what do you get from an iPhone that you can’t get from a blackberry?

A sim only plan is even better. For €31,95 I get 575 minutes and 1150 texts. A decent phone shouldn’t cost more then €60 or so.[/quote]
Well hombre it really depends what you need. I can get a phone for like £30 that’ll make calls and texts fine, or a cameraphone that’ll do the same but take pics, or a walkman phone that’ll do the same but play music…
or I could get a phone that’ll do all that plus web browsing on a great screen (resolution on newer phones like the droid and n1 make browsing the web almost pleasant) and give me a decent API to develop my own apps and a place to buy/download other people’s apps.

Smartphones are called ‘smart’ cuz they can do a whole lot more. Obviously that makes them a whole lot more expensive.

Read full topic

item.title: Nexus one
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

It costs a shitload too. An iPhone for instance. The cheapest plan is €29,95. I have to pay another €29,95 once for the phone. I get 150 texts and 150 minutes. For the same price I can get 600 texts, 300 minutes, and a blackberry bold 9000 (just to name something). In this plan the phone is free. And what do you get from an iPhone that you can’t get from a blackberry?

A sim only plan is even better. For €31,95 I get 575 minutes and 1150 texts. A decent phone shouldn’t cost more then €60 or so.

Read full topic

item.title: Nexus one
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:18, topic:323959”][quote author=TeleNubby link=topic=420359.msg3089852#msg3089852 date=1262813820]
Keyboards themselves are a nice bonus, but I guess you don’t text.
[/quote]

How big is the keyboard? Because there is no feedback, the odds of hitting two keys simultaneously increase dramatically. Too small keys force you to use your index finger to type, which means you have to use two hands. You look like a tool when you do that.

So what does a modern phone have, that an older phone doesn’t? Sure, its great that a 5’ by 2.5’ device has a lot of processing power etc. But how does it put that to use, and does that add any real value to you?[/quote]Yes. I use my phone for various other reasons aside from calling and texting. Remote control over things is nice and web browsing on the go is nice (keep in mind I have it free; I would never pay), etc. I must admit I prefer touch screens but that’s just a personal preference.

Read full topic

item.title: Nexus one
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

TeleNubby:

Keyboards themselves are a nice bonus, but I guess you don’t text.

How big is the keyboard? Because there is no feedback, the odds of hitting two keys simultaneously increase dramatically. Too small keys force you to use your index finger to type, which means you have to use two hands. You look like a tool when you do that.

So what does a modern phone have, that an older phone doesn’t? Sure, its great that a 5’ by 2.5’ device has a lot of processing power etc. But how does it put that to use, and does that add any real value to you?

Read full topic

item.title: Nexus one
item.dc:creator: @mapu mapu
item.description:
@mapu wrote:

[quote=“Stork, post:9, topic:323959”][quote author=mapu link=topic=420359.msg3088501#msg3088501 date=1262696590]

I’m jizzing over it. OLED touchscreen, 800 px wide screen, 1GHz snapdragon cpu. It’s easily the most powerful android phone to date, and it’ll have android 2.1 just for an added bonus.

The press announcement is in about eight hours, I only hope they release this shit in the uk… doubt they will.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: January 05, 2010, 06:55:46 am[/size][hr]just saw this on my rss feed if no one has seen it yet: http://www.engadget.com/2010/01/04/nexus-one-review/

Fuck the u.k. , what’s up with your racist bullshit?
[/quote]
I’m sorry I didn’t quite catch that over the sound of how fucking stupid you are, mind clarifying?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: January 05, 2010, 12:57:51 pm[/size][hr]http://www.google.com/phone[/quote]
I was high, I don’t remember posting this. After reviewing it I think I saw you say “I hope they only release this in the u.k.”

Indeed.

Read full topic

item.title: Nexus one
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:13, topic:323959”]I’m not getting one, i’d pay max $50 for a new phone.[/quote]Why? Sure all you probably need is something that calls and has the ability to vocally communicate with other phones; but still, nowadays there is more to phones than that (at least, I use phones for much more than that). Keyboards themselves are a nice bonus, but I guess you don’t text. Touch screens themselves aren’t great, but they’re usually on phones with newer capabilities and features that older cheaper phones don’t have. I don’t know about you but I prefer newer phones much more to older phones for numerous reasons.

item.title: Nexus one
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

That looks like a pretty decent phone. Beats my current phone (Samsung Behold) and apparently its rumored to “officially” sell with T-Mobile (because T-Mobile’s 3G Network is the “only one that will work”), which is good for me. I might consider getting it.

P.S. Anybody with a T-Mobile phone T-Mobile and wants free internet (browsing the web) without having to pay for a data plan, PM me.

Read full topic

item.title: Nexus one
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

i’ve been into it since like early december, and rumors say it’s being released tomorrow. who is getting it?
links:

en.wikipedia.org

Nexus One

The Nexus One (codenamed HTC Passion) is an Android smartphone designed and manufactured by HTC as Google's first Nexus smartphone. The Nexus became available on January 5, 2010, and features the ability to transcribe voice to text, an additional microphone for dynamic noise suppression, and voice guided turn-by-turn navigation to drivers. The device was sold SIM unlocked and not restricted to use on a single network provider. Google offered T-Mobile US and AT&T versions of the phone online in ...


http://money.cnn.com/2010/01/04/technology/google_nexus_one/
PCWorld

Google's Nexus One Details: What We Know So Far

For all that we know about the Google phone, its business model -- arguably the most interesting thing about it – remains a big question mark.


Engadget

Exclusive: Google Nexus One hands-on, video, and first impressions

That's right, humans -- Engadget has its very own Nexus One. You've seen leaked pics and videos from all over, but we're the first publication to get our very...

i think i’m going to exchange my blackberry bold for one and sell my mytouch 3g

Read full topic
